content.raw: Any idea when this will get out to the debs?
content.html: Any idea when this will get out to the debs?

content.raw:
Hello Jonathan:

We were thinking about the whole picture of releasing 1.4.12 and agreed on not to make the release at all. Here are the reasons:

* At this moment we have the same sdformat version in both, precise and trusty: 1.4.11
* precise sdformat-1.4.11 comes from OSRF or ROS repositories
* trusty sdformat-1.4.11 comes from Ubuntu

We can push into an Ubuntu released distribution only critical bug fixes (one by one), no features or other small patches. I'm afraid that our changes for 1.4.12 are not in this line. This will mean that ROS Indigo users (gazebo2 and sdformat1) won't get the latest fixes on the sdformat_1.4. In the other hand, build our own Trusty sdformat-1.4.12 and host it in OSRF and ROS repositories is an
option but implies more maintenance work (ROS is trying not to host upstream packages).

If you are looking for the moi scaling patch, two ways:

* Compile the sdformat_1.4 branch from source and/or generate your own packages
* Use gazebo4
content.html:
Hello Jonathan:

We were thinking about the whole picture of releasing 1.4.12 and agreed on not to make the release at all. Here are the reasons:

  • At this moment we have the same sdformat version in both, precise and trusty: 1.4.11
  • precise sdformat-1.4.11 comes from OSRF or ROS repositories
  • trusty sdformat-1.4.11 comes from Ubuntu

We can push into an Ubuntu released distribution only critical bug fixes (one by one), no features or other small patches. I'm afraid that our changes for 1.4.12 are not in this line. This will mean that ROS Indigo users (gazebo2 and sdformat1) won't get the latest fixes on the sdformat_1.4. In the other hand, build our own Trusty sdformat-1.4.12 and host it in OSRF and ROS repositories is an option but implies more maintenance work (ROS is trying not to host upstream packages).

If you are looking for the moi scaling patch, two ways:

  • Compile the sdformat_1.4 branch from source and/or generate your own packages
  • Use gazebo4

content.raw:
So as it stands, because of the way that gazebo and sdformat interact, Gazebo 2.2.5 is querying the SDF element "use_dynamic_moi_rescaling", and returning `false` by default because of bool value-type initialization in the `Elem::Get` call. So this is effectively disabling it by default. By not releasing sdformat 1.4.12, all you are doing is preventing people using the DRC sim from using this feature with the released version Gazebo 2. I'm happy with it staying false by default, but I really don't want to see any more behavior changes in patch updates to Gazebo. I especially don't want to see it made `true` by default unless sdformat 1.4.12 is released.

**NOTE: The above is inaccurate, and only occurs if Gazebo 2.2.5 is run with sdformat 1.4.12 in your LD_LIBRARY_PATH**
content.html:
So as it stands, because of the way that gazebo and sdformat interact, Gazebo 2.2.5 is querying the SDF element "use_dynamic_moi_rescaling", and returning false by default because of bool value-type initialization in the Elem::Get call. So this is effectively disabling it by default. By not releasing sdformat 1.4.12, all you are doing is preventing people using the DRC sim from using this feature with the released version Gazebo 2. I'm happy with it staying false by default, but I really don't want to see any more behavior changes in patch updates to Gazebo. I especially don't want to see it made true by default unless sdformat 1.4.12 is released.

NOTE: The above is inaccurate, and only occurs if Gazebo 2.2.5 is run with sdformat 1.4.12 in your LD_LIBRARY_PATH

content.raw: In gazebo 2.2.5, moi rescaling is on by [default](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/72da81d7528585fc2c5e3544d6743af45f2211c4/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc?at=gazebo_2.2#cl-222).  As Jose has stated, we can't release 1.4.12 into Ubuntu and therefore has kept functionality the same. DRC users are our top priority, and we can't change behavior on them.
content.html: In gazebo 2.2.5, moi rescaling is on by default. As Jose has stated, we can't release 1.4.12 into Ubuntu and therefore has kept functionality the same. DRC users are our top priority, and we can't change behavior on them.

content.raw: I don't understand why you can't release 1.4.12 into Ubuntu considering it fixes a critical regression caused by 2.2.3.
content.html: I don't understand why you can't release 1.4.12 into Ubuntu considering it fixes a critical regression caused by 2.2.3.

content.raw: Do we at least agree that Gazebo 2.2.2 -> 2.2.3 was a regression, as per https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/1272/gazebo-223-broke-simulation-stability ?
content.html: Do we at least agree that Gazebo 2.2.2 -> 2.2.3 was a regression, as per https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/1272/gazebo-223-broke-simulation-stability ?

content.raw: Yeah, so after all this, I'm still expected to build sdformat from source if I don't want my simulation to go unstable.
content.html: Yeah, so after all this, I'm still expected to build sdformat from source if I don't want my simulation to go unstable.
